title: The twins who tricked the Maya gods of death - Ilan Stavans

multiple-choice.question: What activity did the twin brothers, Jun and Wuqub, engage in that disturbed the lords of the underworld?
What happened to Jun's head after he was killed by the lords of the underworld?

options.label: A
options.text: It was buried in a grave

options.label: B
options.text: It was hung from a tree as a trophy

options.label: C
options.text: It was given to his brother

options.label: D
options.text: It was thrown into a river

multiple-choice.question: How did the skull of Jun impregnate the lord's daughter?
What was the name of the twin sons born to the lord's daughter?
What challenge did the messengers from the underworld issue to the second generation of twins?
How did the twins discover the lords who had challenged them in the great city?

options.label: B
options.text: By sending a mosquito to sting the figures

multiple-choice.question: What was the condition given to the twins for spending the night in the House of Darkness?

options.label: A
options.text: They had to return a torch lit

options.label: B
options.text: They had to return a torch unburnt

options.label: C
options.text: They had to stay awake all night

multiple-choice.question: What was hidden inside the ball used by the lords in the game?

options.label: C
options.text: A weapon to kill the twins

multiple-choice.question: How did Ixb'alanke trick the lords in the House of Bats?

options.label: B
options.text: By swapping Junajpu's head with a carved squash

multiple-choice.question: What was the final outcome for the lords of the underworld after the twins' curse?

options.label: A
options.text: They gained more power over humans

options.label: B
options.text: They were given a second chance

options.label: C
options.text: They had no sacrifices and no power over the surface world

title: The sleep disorder you might not know you have - Alayna Vaughan

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary cause of snoring?

options.label: B
options.text: The vibration of relaxed tissues in the respiratory tract

options.label: C
options.text: The position in which one sleeps

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the sleep disorder characterized by loud, chronic snoring and pauses in breathing during sleep?
What percentage of people who suffer from obstructive sleep apnea are estimated to be unaware they have it?
What is the primary difference between obstructive sleep apnea and central sleep apnea?

options.label: A
options.text: Obstructive sleep apnea is caused by blockages in the airway, while central sleep apnea is caused by the brain's failure to regulate breathing.

options.label: B
options.text: Obstructive sleep apnea is more common than central sleep apnea.

options.label: C
options.text: Central sleep apnea is characterized by louder snoring.

options.label: D
options.text: Obstructive sleep apnea only occurs in older adults.

multiple-choice.question: What is a common consequence of experiencing obstructive sleep apnea?
What is a common symptom experienced by people with obstructive sleep apnea?
What is a factor that can increase a person's risk of developing obstructive sleep apnea?
What is a behavioral shift that may help alleviate obstructive sleep apnea?

options.label: D
options.text: Consuming a large meal before bed

multiple-choice.question: What is a common treatment for obstructive sleep apnea?
Why do doctors usually aim to remedy sleep apnea with non-invasive treatments first?

options.label: C
options.text: Because they are less invasive and may be sufficient

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are only available for mild cases

title: 3 secrets of resilient people - Lucy Hone

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what event led her to question her expertise in resilience research?

options.label: B
options.text: The death of her 12-year-old daughter Abi

multiple-choice.question: What did the speaker find unhelpful about the advice she received after her daughter's death?

options.label: A
options.text: It was too focused on the positive

options.label: B
options.text: It was too focused on the negative

options.label: C
options.text: It made her feel like a victim

multiple-choice.question: What is the first strategy for resilience mentioned by the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: Choosing where to focus your attention

options.label: B
options.text: Asking yourself if what you're doing is helping or harming you

options.label: C
options.text: Recognizing that suffering is a part of life

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the problem with the way our brains are wired to respond to threats?

options.label: A
options.text: We are too focused on the positive

options.label: B
options.text: We are too focused on the negative

options.label: C
options.text: We are not focused enough on the present

options.label: D
options.text: We are not focused enough on the future

multiple-choice.question: What is the term used in psychology to describe the practice of finding things to be grateful for?
According to the speaker, what was the result of Martin Seligman's experiment on gratitude?

options.label: A
options.text: Participants showed lower levels of gratitude and happiness

options.label: B
options.text: Participants showed higher levels of gratitude and happiness

options.label: C
options.text: Participants showed no change in gratitude and happiness

options.label: D
options.text: Participants showed a decrease in depression

multiple-choice.question: What is the third strategy for resilience mentioned by the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: Choosing where to focus your attention

options.label: B
options.text: Asking yourself if what you're doing is helping or harming you

options.label: C
options.text: Recognizing that suffering is a part of life

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the benefit of asking yourself if what you're doing is helping or harming you?

options.label: A
options.text: It gives you more time to think about your decisions

options.label: B
options.text: It gives you more control over your decision-making

options.label: C
options.text: It helps you avoid making decisions altogether

options.label: D
options.text: It helps you make decisions more quickly

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's main message about resilience?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a fixed trait that some people have and some people don't

options.label: B
options.text: It requires special training or expertise

options.label: C
options.text: It is not possible to develop resilience

options.label: D
options.text: It requires ordinary processes and a willingness to try

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what has she learned about resilience over the last five years?

options.label: A
options.text: It is not possible to live and grieve at the same time

options.label: B
options.text: It is possible to live and grieve at the same time

options.label: C
options.text: Resilience is only for people who have experienced trauma

options.label: D
options.text: Resilience is only for people who are naturally optimistic

title: The simplest math problem no one can solve

multiple-choice.question: What is the Collatz conjecture?

options.label: A
options.text: A mathematical problem that deals with the properties of prime numbers.

options.label: B
options.text: A conjecture that states every positive integer will eventually end up in the four, two, one loop when applying the 3x+1 rules.

options.label: C
options.text: A theorem that describes the behavior of geometric Brownian motion.

options.label: D
options.text: A problem that involves finding the leading digit of a sequence of numbers.

multiple-choice.question: What are the two rules applied to a number in the Collatz conjecture?

options.label: A
options.text: If the number is odd, divide by 2, and if the number is even, multiply by 3 and add 1.

options.label: B
options.text: If the number is odd, multiply by 3 and add 1, and if the number is even, divide by 2.

options.label: C
options.text: If the number is odd, multiply by 2, and if the number is even, divide by 3.

options.label: D
options.text: If the number is odd, divide by 3, and if the number is even, multiply by 2.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the mathematician who said, "Mathematics is not yet ripe enough for such questions"?
What is the term used to describe the numbers obtained by applying the 3x+1 rules?
What is the pattern observed in the leading digits of the hailstone numbers?
What is the name of the mathematician who proved that almost all Collatz sequences reach a point below their initial value?
What is the largest number that has been tested by brute force to see if it obeys the Collatz conjecture?
What is the term used to describe a mathematical machine that can do anything a modern computer can do?
What is the name of the mathematician who created a generalization of the Collatz conjecture called FRACTRAN?
What is the name of the problem that states that there is no general algorithm that can determine whether a given program will run forever or eventually stop?

title: What few people know about the program that "saved" America - Meg Jacobs

multiple-choice.question: What was the unemployment rate in the United States in 1932?
Who was the Republican President of the United States in 1932?
What was the name of the comprehensive set of legislation proposed by Franklin D. Roosevelt to support struggling citizens and put the country back to work?
What was the primary goal of the Federal Emergency Relief Administration (FERA)?

options.label: A
options.text: To provide jobs for young men

options.label: C
options.text: To catalog each state's need for relief and provide funds to help citizens afford necessities

multiple-choice.question: What was the name of the program established to employ young men in projects such as tree planting, irrigation, and fire prevention?
What was the result of the labor acts passed during the New Deal?

options.label: D
options.text: Child labor was abolished, unions were granted the right to collective bargaining, and the first national minimum wage was set

multiple-choice.question: What was the impact of the New Deal on Black communities in the South?

options.label: A
options.text: They received a large share of jobs and vocational training

options.label: B
options.text: They received an influx of public housing

options.label: C
options.text: New labor laws excluded domestic servants and agricultural workers, occupations held by many Black Americans

options.label: D
options.text: The New Deal had no impact on Black communities in the South

multiple-choice.question: Why is the New Deal often referred to as a "raw deal" for Black communities?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it provided too many jobs for Black Americans

options.label: B
options.text: Because it provided too much public housing for Black Americans

options.label: C
options.text: Because it prioritized white Americans and excluded many Black Americans from its benefits

options.label: D
options.text: Because it had no impact on Black communities

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of the New Deal's efforts to reduce unemployment?

options.label: C
options.text: Unemployment was cut in half, but never went lower than 14%

multiple-choice.question: What was the long-term impact of the New Deal on the Democratic Party?

options.label: A
options.text: It led to the decline of the Democratic Party

options.label: B
options.text: It led to the rise of the Republican Party

options.label: C
options.text: It reshaped the Democratic Party, challenging its racist leadership and laying the groundwork for an emerging civil rights coalition

options.label: D
options.text: It had no impact on the Democratic Party

title: The epic of Gilgamesh, the king who tried to conquer death - Soraya Field Fiorio

multiple-choice.question: In what year did archaeologists discover the ancient library in Nineveh, Iraq, which contained the Epic of Gilgamesh?

What was the name of the creature with a thousand faces that Gilgamesh and Enkidu slew in the Forest of Cedar?
Why did the goddess Ishtar unleash the Bull of Heaven on the city of Uruk?

options.label: A
options.text: Because Gilgamesh and Enkidu slew Humbaba

options.label: B
options.text: Because Gilgamesh refused her romantic advances

options.label: C
options.text: Because Enkidu was seduced by a priestess of Ishtar

According to the Epic of Gilgamesh, how did Utanapishti become immortal?

options.label: A
options.text: He was granted immortality by the gods for his bravery

options.label: B
options.text: He built a boat and survived a great flood

options.label: C
options.text: He retrieved a magical plant from the ocean

options.label: A
options.text: To slay the Bull of Heaven

options.label: B
options.text: To retrieve a magical plant from the ocean

options.label: C
options.text: To conquer sleep for seven days

options.label: D
options.text: To build a boat and survive a great flood

multiple-choice.question: What happened to the magical plant that granted eternal youth, which Gilgamesh retrieved from the ocean?

options.label: A
options.text: He used it to become immortal

options.label: B
options.text: He gave it to Enkidu to bring him back to life

options.label: C
options.text: A snake stole it on his way home

options.label: D
options.text: He lost it in the Forest of Cedar

multiple-choice.question: What did Gilgamesh do with his story after he returned to Uruk and made peace with his mortality?

options.label: A
options.text: He told it to the people of Uruk

options.label: B
options.text: He wrote it on a lapis lazuli tablet and buried it under the city walls

options.label: C
options.text: He gave it to the goddess Ishtar

options.label: D
options.text: He took it with him on his travels
